Sure! "Change in ETDRS BCVA" - The Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) Better Reading Vision Acuity (BCVA) chart is commonly used in clinical practice to assess visual acuity. The ETDRS letter graphics, similar to the Snellen graphics, are presented in a large field of view with an oculographic base line, which facilitates quantification of visual acuity by examiner or machine, and a calibrated magnified field containing the optotypes in standard sizes for subject acuity estimation. The ETDRS charts use 6 letter graphics ranging from 1/4 to 7/800 from LogMAR (LogMar = logarithm of the Minimum Angle of Resolution). The optotypes are presented in a darker (circa 5-7.5% luminance) surrounding ring against a uniform field of 15 to 19 luminance, thus minimizing extraneous light influences on patients and examiner. BCVA is measured by marking the optotype with the longest letter through which the patient can read lines of the acuity percent (e.g. 4/10 is marked when the patient can read 4 lines in 10 feet). The optotypes are tested sequentially in a "least-intercept" procedure, where the optotype which is identified first, with at least 5 consecutive correct responses of "1" or "2", is taken as VA. VA in each eye is measured and averaged, and is tested at maximum correct responses of 4 and 5 for "worst" eye and eye with "best" vision, respectively. The corrected distance VA is the visual acuity in both eyes combined, converted to a letter equivalency with regression based on the patients' correct response criteria. The measure of interest is the change in visual acuity from baseline to follow-up visit in meters of the Snellen acuity chart (e.g. a decrease of 1 letter indicates worsening from baseline).
"Change in CNV": The incidence, size and characteristics of choroidal neovascularization (CNV) is estimated semi-quantitatively by an examiner for each eye using a detailed, standardized, reproducible

Primary Outcome Measure:
- pCR: The absence of malignant cells in surgical samples. The pCR rate will be evaluated after surgery, an average of 4 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- R0 resection rate: Complete removal of the tumor in the operation with microscopically negative margins. Evaluated after surgery, an average of 4 weeks.
- 3-year overall survival rate: Rate of overall survival for 3 years. Assessed from randomization until the date of death from any cause, up to 3 years.
- 3-year disease-free survival rate: Rate of disease-free survival for 3 years. Assessed from randomization until the date of first documented progression or death from any cause, up to 3 years.
- Grade 3-4 adverse effects rate: Rate of severe adverse events related to chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and immunotherapy. Assessed from randomization until death from any cause, up to 5 years.
- 3-year local recurrence-free survival rate: Rate of local recurrence-free survival for 3 years. Assessed from randomization until the date of first documented local-regional failure, up to 3 years.
- Surgical complications: Rate of surgical complications, such as intraoperative hemorrhage, anastomotic leakage, intestinal obstruction, etc. Assessed up to 5 years from the surgery.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Physical Activity Scale for the Physically Disabled (PASIPD): This 13-item scale assesses activities of daily living, domestic activities, and professional duties over the last 7 days. The time frame for measuring the PASIPD is 7 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale: This scale consists of 43 items and assesses the individual's level of belief in the benefit of exercise. The time frame for measuring the Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale is 7 months.
- Berg Balance Scale (BBS): This 14-item scale evaluates balance and fall risk. It measures the patient's ability to maintain balance while performing static or various functional movements. The time frame for measuring the BBS is 7 months.
- International Fall Effectiveness Scale (FES-I): This scale assesses the self-confidence of individuals in daily activities and their fear of falling. The time frame for measuring the FES-I is 7 months.
- Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS): This scale assesses the fatigue status of individuals over the past week. Those with an FSS score of 4 or higher are considered tired. The time frame for measuring the FSS is 7 months.
- Beck Depression Inventory (BDI): This inventory measures the symptoms of depression. It consists of 21 items graded between 0 and 3 points. The time frame for measuring the BDI is 7 months.
- Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI): This scale assesses the quality of sleep and disturbances experienced by individuals over the past month. The time frame for measuring the PSQI is 7 months.

model_response: The AUC summarizes the total exposure of the drug in the body over a period of time, while Cmax represents the maximum concentration of the drug in the bloodstream. By comparing the AUC and Cmax values of the two formulations under investigation, we can determine if they are bioequivalent. If the 90% confidence interval of the ratio of their AUC values falls within the predetermined bioequivalence limits, it indicates that the two formulations are equivalent.

The preferred method to measure the AUC and Cmax is by using a pharmacokinetic model followed by blood sampling and HPLC-MS/MS or LC-MS/MS analysis. The sampling should be performed at specific time points throughout the dosing interval and preferably at 0, 1, 2, 4, 8, 12, and 24 hours after dosing.

For the AUC, I would recommend using the SAS data analysis software to plot the data and then estimate the area under the concentration-time curve from 0-72 hours using the trapezoidal method. To measure the Cmax, I would simply measure the maximum concentration after dosing.
Given the long half-life of Lamotrigine, we would need to collect blood samples at multiple time points up to 72 hours after the start of dosing.

groundtruth: Certainly! The AUC represents the total exposure of the drug in the body over time, while the Cmax indicates the peak concentration of the drug in the blood after administration. By analyzing both AUC and Cmax, we can assess the rate and extent of drug absorption, which is crucial in determining the bioequivalence of the two Lamotrigine tablets.

To measure the AUC and Cmax, we will collect blood samples at various time points up to 72 hours after the administration of the drug. model_response: Sure, knee proprioception deficit can be measured in various ways. One reliable and commonly used assessment tool is the proprioception dot test. It involves asking the patient to stand on a raised platform and identify which of the four arrows (N, E, W, S, and X) point to the four corners of the room. This test can help measure the ability of the patient to perceive spatial orientation and position of the body in space. As for the gait and balance parameters, we can use the walkway test and the center of pressure analysis to assess the walking pattern and trunk movement during gait. You can also evaluate the static balance and sensory organization by assessing the Romberg and Timed Up-and-Go tests. Another important aspect is measuring the reaction time to sudden visual and auditory stimuli, as this is directly related to the proprioception. These response time measurements can be done using either the Modified Rosenbaum Test or the Choice Reaction Time tests.

model_response: It's important to design an effective outcome measure for prevention studies because the effects of an intervention are usually not seen until hours, days, or even weeks after the intervention is completed. The best examples of outcome measures for a prevention study involve biological markers or actual clinical outcomes such as HIV infection or progression to AIDS. Because your study focuses on a behavioral intervention, it may be challenging to identify an appropriate primary outcome measure. Some possible measures could be self-reported HIV serostatus or intention to have unprotected sex, but these are subject to recall bias and don't provide a definitive assessment of the intervention's effect. One outcome measure that might be effective for a behavioral intervention like your study is incidence, which quantifies the rate at which HIV infections occur during the course of the study. This measure can provide a more objective assessment of the impact of the intervention on HIV transmission. It should be noted that incidence is more challenging and expensive to measure than serostatus or intention. I'd be happy to discuss these and other potential measures with you.

model_response: An interventional study, also called an intervention study, tests a new treatment or intervention. In an interventional study, the investigators directly interfere with theSubject's usual course of treatment, which can include giving them a drug or another treatment to see if it has potential benefit. A Phase 0 or Phase I study is one in which the investigators usually assess a drug or intervention on a small group of people (20-80) for the very first time to evaluate its safety, pharmacological effects, pharmacokinetics (the way the drug moves in the body), pharmacodynamics (how the drug affects the body), adverse effects, dosage, method of administration, and how it is processed in the body. Please provide me with more details about your study type and phase and I will suggest appropriate outcomes.

Consider the logistics of implementing and supervising the aerobic exercise training program. It may be necessary to have an exercise physiologist or physical therapist to run the intervention and monitor the exercise dose delivered. The aerobic exercise training may span over the course of 12-24 weeks, which require multiple supervision sessions. 2. The study should have a 3 to 1 staff/participant ratio to ensure participant safety and adherence to the exercise program. The number of exercises sessions per week or minutes/time spent in exercise will need to be specified. Consider the cost of supervision and sessions. Who will pay for the supervision costs? Will participants be reimbursed? 3. If not supervised in office, safety considerations must be considered. What is the control group receiving? Is there a group receiving no intervention? This is necessary to ensure that it is the exercise training that leads to any change and not the no-intervention control. A no-supervision group may be a problem due to increased drop-out rate. What are your thoughts on these considerations? 4. There are ethical considerations with an allocation concealment. If randomization is assigned, will it be revealed at study baseline or at the first exercise session? This will ensure the randomization is not "by-passed". If deception of the allocation is necessary, it must be disclosed and consented. A possible solution would be to have an unblinded crossover group or an open label group if the intervention effect is expected to be small. 5. It isn't clear if the dose of exercise is specific to each participant or for the entire group. It is more physiologic to have the exercise dose specific to each participant and would prevent one group from slacking off while the other exercises at the highest dose. On the other hand, if the groups are crossed over, the more responsive individuals may do more than the minimum and the less responsive may not achieve the intervention. Would an adaptive design (start at a low dose and then increasing based on response) make sense? What do you think? I think the allocation concealment could be revealed at

Incidence of study-related adverse events can be measured from the date of first treatment to 90 days after the last treatment. Pathological response can be assessed from the date of first treatment to radiographically documented progression or death from any cause, with an assessment period of up to 5 years. Disease control rate (DCR) can be measured from the date of first treatment to radiographically documented response according to mRECIST, assessed up to 3 years. Duration of response can be defined as the time from first documented evidence of complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) until the first documented sign of disease progression (PD) or death from any cause. Lastly, quality of life (QoL) after treatment can be assessed from the date of first follow-up to radiographically documented progression or death from any cause, up to 3 years. How does this sound?

Perfect! We now have a comprehensive set of primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial on the inactivated rotavirus vaccine. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean titer (GMT) of neutralizing antibody: Measure the GMT of neutralizing antibodies 28 days after the final dose.
2. Immunogenicity index-geometric mean increase (GMI) of neutralizing antibody: Assess the increase in neutralizing antibodies from baseline to 28 days after the final dose.
3. Immunogenicity index-seroconversion rates of neutralizing antibody: Determine the proportion of participants who develop a seropositive response between baseline and 28 days after the final dose.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Safety index-incidence of adverse reactions/events: Monitor the incidence of adverse reactions/events within 30 minutes after each dose.
2. Safety index-incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events: Assess the incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events within 7 days after each dose.
3. Safety index-incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events: Evaluate the incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events within 28/30 days after each dose.
4. Safety index-incidence of serious adverse events: Track the occurrence of serious adverse reactions/events from the beginning of vaccination up to 6 months after the final dose.

Is there anything else I can help you with regarding the outcome measures for your clinical trial?

model_response: The Modified Rankin Scale is a tool used to assess the functional outcome in stroke survivors. It ranges from 0 to 6, with 0 indicating full recovery, 1-2 indicating no change in ability to perform activities of daily living, and 6 indicating total disability. It can be assessed at 3 months and 1 year after the hemorrhagic event. This will allow us to measure the impact of statin treatment on functional outcomes and disability in patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage.

The Barthel Scale measures independent self-care abilities, with a score of 100 representing total independent function and 0 representing complete disability. We can use the Barthel Scale at the start of the study and a few times during the hospital stay (up to 14 days). This will allow us to track changes in self-care abilities and the ability to perform activities of daily living, which is important in evaluating the impact of statin treatment. Finally, what about mortality?

Yes, of course. We can assess mortality by reviewing medical history and physical examination findings and by regularly monitoring vital signs. The number of deaths can be counted and the time to death can be measured. This will help us understand the mortality rate of statin treatment compared to the control group and also help in monitoring adverse effect s of the treatment. This is an important measure to evaluate the overall safety profile of statins in patients with intracerebral hemorrhage.

Primary and secondary outcome measures are tools used to assess the efficacy and safety of interventions. In clinical trials, the primary outcome measures are the ones that answer the research question or the purpose of the study. Secondary outcome measures are those that provide additional information about the effect of the intervention, but are not the main focus of the study. In the example we just discussed, the primary outcome measure is mortality, which is what the researchers are primarily interested in knowing. The secondary outcome measures are neurological function (measured by NIHSS and Barthel scale), recovery of self-care abilities (measured by Barthel scale), and the incidence of adverse effects (measured by the number of deaths or adverse effects during the hospital stay and up to 90 days after treatment). These measures provide additional information on the impact of statin therapy on clinically relevant outcomes and patient safety.
That sounds like a good list. Yes, we could include those measures as secondary outcome measures.

We can evaluate the Barthel Scale during the hospital stay (up to 14 days) and up to 90 days. model_response: The number of participants experiencing dose-limiting toxicities is an important measure of safety and pharmacokinetics. Dose-limiting toxicities are any side effects that prevent participants from continuing receiving the drug at a particular dose. By monitoring this measure, we can see how well the drug is tolerated at different dose levels. This helps to assess whether the drug is safe and effective at the desired dosage.

The RP2D is determined as the dose at which no more than one participant experiences dose-limiting toxicities at any dose. This is calculated using the smallest Cmax and AUC. The recommended phase 2 dose is the maximum dose at which no more than one participant experiences dose-limiting toxicities while on-treatment. This dose is considered the optimal dose for further study.

The maximum concentration (Cmax) and area under the curve (AUC) of BAY2862789 are important parameters to monitor in this study as they help us understand how the drug is being absorbed and eliminated from the body. This information is used to make decisions about dose escalation or deescalation, and to assess drug exposure and drug-drug interactions.

Yes, of course. The secondary outcome measures in this study may include response rate, progression-free survival (PFS), duration of response, total tumor burden, and best tumor diameter. Response rate refers to the proportion of participants with complete or partial responses, progression-free survival (PFS) is the time during which the patient's disease does not progress, duration of response is the time between the start of therapy and disease progression, total tumor burden is the sum of the longest diameters of all target lesions, and best tumor diameter is the greatest largest size of any target lesion. These measures help us evaluate the effectiveness of the drug and are important for drug development.

The objective response rate (ORR) measures the proportion of participants with complete response (CR) and partial response (PR). Complete response means that all target lesions have disappeared, while partial response means that there is a decrease in the sum of the target lesion's longest diameter by ≥ 50% and no new lesions have appeared.

The disease control rate (DCR) is defined as the proportion of participants whose best response is either a PR or stable disease (SD) per RECIST 1.1. It helps us evaluate the magnitude of the overall tumor response to BAY2862789.

DOR is measured from the onset of the first evidence of objective response without evidence of disease progression. The duration of response is one of the key measures of efficacy in cancer treatment.

Progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months represents the proportion of participants from the starting date of protocol-stem cell or disease-chronic-start date that are progression-free at 6 months. PFS is an end-points used to assess whether a treatment is beneficial at controlling the disease by calculating the patients who experience disease progression or death by 6 months in comparison to those who do not.

Overall survival (OS) at 12 months is defined as the time from the start of study treatment to death due to any cause. It reflects the ultimate outcome of treatment and is the most relevant and meaningful measure of mortality.
The measures related to activation of effector T memory cells and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of IL2 and interferon-gamma help evaluate the immunogenicity of BAY2862789.
groundtruth: The number of participants experiencing dose-limiting toxicities at each dose level in the Dose Escalation part of the study helps us determine the maximum tolerated dose of BAY2862789. Dose-limiting toxicities are adverse events that are considered too severe or intolerable to continue treatment. By monitoring these toxicities, we can identify the highest dose that can be safely administered to participants.

The recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) is determined in the expansion part of the study based on multiple parameters, including safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and efficacy. The final decision about the RP2D is made by the Sponsor in consultation with the Investigators. The RP2D represents the dose of BAY2862789 that will be used in future phase 2 studies.

Monitoring the maximum concentration (Cmax) and area under the curve (AUC) of BAY2862789 after single and multiple doses helps us understand the drug's pharmacokinetic profile. Cmax reflects the highest level of the drug in the blood, while AUC represents the total exposure of the drug in the body over time. These measures are important for optimizing dosing regimens and assessing the drug's efficacy and safety.

The secondary outcome measures for this clinical trial include the objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), duration of response (DOR), progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months, overall survival (OS) at 12 months, activation of effector T memory cells, and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of Interleukin 2 (IL2) and interferon-gamma. These measures focus on evaluating the efficacy of BAY2862789 in terms of tumor response, disease control, survival outcomes, and immunological effects.

Certainly! The objective response rate (ORR) is defined as the proportion of participants whose best overall response is either a confirmed complete response (CR) or confirmed partial response (PR) according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST 1.1). ORR helps us assess how effective BAY2862789 is in shrinking or stabilizing tumors.

The disease control rate (DCR) is defined as the percentage of participants whose best overall response was either complete response (CR), partial response (PR), or stable disease (SD). DCR considers the requirement for confirmation of CR and PR. It provides a broader understanding of the treatment's impact on disease control by considering not only tumor shrinkage but also stability.

The duration of response (DOR) is defined as the time from the first documented objective response of PR or CR, whichever occurs earlier, to disease progression or death (if death occurs before progression is documented). It helps us understand how long the treatment's effects last in terms of tumor response. DOR is an important measure of the sustainability of treatment response.

Progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months measures the time from the start of study treatment to the date of first observed disease progression by investigator assessment or death due to any cause, if death occurs before progression is documented. It provides valuable information on the treatment's ability to delay disease progression for at least 6 months.

Overall survival (OS) at 12 months measures the time from the start of study treatment to death due to any cause. It helps us evaluate the treatment's impact on prolonging overall survival. OS at 12 months provides important information on the long-term benefits of BAY2862789.

Monitoring the activation of effector T memory cells and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of IL2 and interferon-gamma helps us assess the immunological effects of BAY2862789. These measures provide insights into the drug's impact on T cell activation and cytokine production, which are important for understanding its mechanism of action and potential anti-cancer effects mediated through the immune system.

Yes, we use tracking codes to ensure that participants receive the full set of 40 text messages as well as any "booster" messages. The secondary outcome measures are specific to each of the individual intervention arms. For the Dietary Quality arm, they include the Mediterranean Diet Score, a self-reported 24-hour dietary recall, an inventory of dietary health behaviors, body weight, BMI, and satisfaction with the intervention. For the Physical Activity arm, there are 3-day physical activity diaries, a 7-day accelerometer, and an exercise self-efficacy scale. For the Sleep Hygiene arm, there are sleep diaries, a sleep quality self-report inventory, and a 7-day actigraph.

Self-report measures such as questionnaires and surveys can be used to assess the acceptability of the text messages. Specifically, you can ask participants to rate each message on a 0 to 5 scale from "strongly disagree" to "strongly agree" to assess their acceptability. Participants may be asked to answer this question after each text message is delivered. This outcome measure is important to assess the acceptability of the text message intervention with the participants. If the texts are not perceived as acceptable, it may impact the adherence to the intervention and the effectiveness of the program.

To measure engagement with the text messages, you can track the number of responses to the messages. This outcome measure provides information on the degree of participation and interaction between the participants and the intervention. Monitoring the response rate can help you determine whether the messages are relevant and timely for the participants and if changes need to be made to improve the intervention.

To measure changes in dietary quality, you can use the Healthy Eating Index 2015 (HEI-2015) questionnaire. The HEI-2015 score is a measure of the overall adherence to the 2015 Dietary Guidelines for Americans in a person's diet. It uses a 100-point scale, with a higher score indicating a healthier diet.  Changes in the HEI-2015 score can be used to assess the effects of the intervention on dietary quality.

The International Physical Activity Questionnaire is a tool used to assess physical activity level. To measure changes in physical activity, you can have participants complete the questionnaire at baseline and after the intervention period. This will provide data on changes in physical activity level resulting from the intervention.

The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index is a valid tool for assessing sleep hygiene behaviors. To measure changes in sleep hygiene behaviors, you can administer the questionnaire to participants at baseline and after the 4-week intervention period. The questionnaire will give you information on changes in sleep hygiene behaviors following the intervention.

Great! We have now discussed the primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. Albumin degradation rate by stable isotope:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to determine the catabolic rate of albumin by measuring the disappearance rate of 2H5-phenylalanine labeled albumin over time in blood samples. It will be compared between patients with liver disease and healthy volunteers.
   - Time Frame: The albumin degradation rate will be measured over a period of 12 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Albumin synthesis rate:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing the oral flooding dose with historical controls where the isotope was given intravenously to measure albumin synthesis rates in volunteers and patients with liver disease.
   - Time Frame: The albumin synthesis rate will be assessed within 120 minutes after the administration of the stable isotope labeled amino acid.

2. Albumin degradation by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over time:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to investigate the relationship between oxidation and degradation of albumin by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over a period of 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The modeling of albumin degradation based on oxidized fractions will be conducted over a 12-week period.

3. Correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure seeks to determine if there is a correlation between oxidation fraction and albumin degradation rate, particularly in patients with liver disease over 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin will be assessed over a 12-week period.

By analyzing these variables, we can gain insights into the effectiveness of peripheral airway biopsy in different patient populations. The time frame for assessing these measures would be 6 months to allow for comprehensive evaluation over time.

Certainly! For the diagnostic yield according to sex, we will assess the association between male and female patients and the diagnostic yield of peripheral airway biopsy. The same approach will be taken for ethnicity, comparing white individuals with those of other ethnicities. We will also explore the association between a history of malignancy (presence versus absence of any malignancy diagnosed within 5 years of the procedure) and the diagnostic yield. Additionally, the sarcoidosis stage at CT (I vs II vs III vs IV) will be considered to evaluate its impact on the diagnostic yield. Lastly, we will assess the association between the presence of endoscopically visible large airway abnormalities and the diagnostic yield of peripheral airway biopsy.

2. Decision-to-arrival time: Time from decision for MT to arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center. Time frame: 24 hours.

3. Arrival-to-groin time: Time from arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center to groin puncture (start of mechanical thrombectomy procedure). Time frame: 24 hours.

4. Rate of refusal of transfer requests due to lack of capacity: Rate of patients that had to be transferred to a secondary thrombectomy center instead of the primary thrombectomy center due to lack of capacity in the referral clinic. Time frame: 24 hours.

5. Decision-to-transfer request time: Time from decision for MT to request of emergency medical service for interhospital transfer. Time frame: 24 hours.

6. Periprocedural complications: Rate of periprocedural complications during MT. Time frame: 24 hours.

7. Successful outcome of MT (mTICI > 2b): Rate of successfully performed MT (mTICI > 2b) of all patients with attempted MT. Time frame: 24 hours.

8. Groin-to-recanalization time: Time from groin puncture to successful recanalization. Time frame: 24 hours.

9. Adverse events within 7 days: Adverse events within the first 7 days after transfer to the referral center. Time frame: 7 days.

Absolutely! In addition to the CR/CRh rate, there are several other important secondary outcome measures to consider. These include:

1. Incidence and severity of adverse events (safety and tolerability): We can monitor the number and grade of adverse events assessed by CTCAE v5.0 over the course of approximately 36 months. This will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy.

2. Duration of response: Measuring the time from randomization to disease progression or death in patients who achieve CR/CRh will provide insights into the durability of treatment response.

3. Post baseline transfusion independence rate: Assessing the rate of conversion from baseline transfusion dependence to transfusion independence will help us understand the impact of treatment on patients' quality of life.

4. Progression-free survival: Evaluating the time from randomization until the first evidence of disease progression or death will provide valuable information on the treatment's ability to control disease progression and prolong survival.

5. Relapse-free survival: Monitoring the number of participants alive without relapse will help us assess the long-term effectiveness of the combination therapy in preventing disease relapse.

6. Overall survival: Measuring the time from randomization to death will provide essential data on the treatment's impact on overall survival outcomes.

7. Percentage of patients bridged to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Assessing the number of hematopoietic stem cell transplantations following response will provide insights into the potential of the combination therapy to facilitate curative treatment options.

8. Impact of treatment on HM-PRO (hematologic malignancy-specific patient-reported outcome measure): Evaluating the treatment's impact on patients' health-related quality of life and disease-related signs and symptoms using the HM-PRO scales will provide a holistic understanding of the treatment's effects.

Along with FEV1, it would be beneficial to include additional secondary outcome measures to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the impact of non-tailpipe emissions on respiratory health. I suggest considering the following secondary outcome measures:

1. Forced Vital Capacity (FVC): FVC is another important measure of lung function that complements FEV1. It would provide additional insights into respiratory function. We can measure FVC at 0 hours, 2.5 hours, and 26 hours after exposure.

2. Fractional expired Nitric Oxide (FeNO): FeNO is a marker of airway inflammation and is commonly elevated in individuals with asthma. Monitoring changes in FeNO before and after exposure to different air quality environments can provide valuable insights into the inflammatory response of the airways. We can measure FeNO at 0 hours, 2.5 hours, and 26 hours after exposure.

3. Daily asthma symptoms: Assessing changes in asthma symptoms through a validated questionnaire would provide important clinical information about the impact of non-tailpipe emissions on asthma control and quality of life. We can measure asthma symptoms at 0 hours, 2.5 hours, and 26 hours after exposure.

4. Immune response: This outcome measure focuses on assessing specific immune markers related to airway inflammation and damage. We can measure DAMPs, alarmins, cytokines, and metal deposition in the nasal airways at 0 hours, 2.5 hours, and 26 hours after exposure.

5. Airway resistance: Impulse oscillometry is a non-invasive method for assessing airway resistance, which can provide valuable information about changes in lung function and airway mechanics. We can measure airway resistance at 0 hours, 2.5 hours, and 26 hours after exposure.

What are your thoughts on these secondary outcome measures?

I would suggest considering the following outcome measures:
1. Auditory brainstem response (ABR) intensity: This measure provides objective information about the integrity of the auditory pathway from the ear to the brainstem. It can help monitor the progression of hearing loss in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure ABR intensity at different time points throughout the study, such as annually for 4 years.

Another important measure is otoacoustic emission (OAEs) amplitudes. OAEs are a non-invasive measure of cochlear function and can provide information about the health of the outer hair cells in the cochlea. Monitoring OAEs amplitudes can help assess the structural integrity of the cochlea and detect early signs of cochlear dysfunction in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can also measure OAEs amplitudes annually for 4 years.

Yes, we should include pure tone intensity thresholds as an outcome measure. This measure assesses the softest sound that a participant can hear at different frequencies. It's crucial for evaluating the degree and configuration of hearing loss and tracking changes in hearing sensitivity over time in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure pure tone intensity thresholds annually for 4 years as well.

The last outcome measure I would recommend is speech detection and perception thresholds. This measure evaluates the ability of participants to detect and perceive speech sounds at different intensity levels. It's important for understanding the impact of gene-related hearing loss on speech understanding and communication abilities in pediatric participants. We can assess speech detection and perception thresholds annually for 4 years.

For secondary outcome measures, I suggest focusing on auditory skills and speech perception over time. We can include measures such as open- and closed-set task phoneme accuracy and word comprehension, early speech perception (ESP), pediatric speech intelligibility (PSI) test, and auditory skills checklist (ASC). These measures will provide insights into the development of auditory skills and speech perception abilities in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can assess these measures annually for 4 years as well.

Of course! Static footprint is an invaluable measure of plantar forces in standing. The assessment protocol for static footprints includes standing on a force plate with the arms at the subject's sides. The plantar fore-foot pressure distribution is plotted as a two-dimensional force map to assess pressure areas and distribution. This method has been proven to be effective in measuring subtle changes in pressure distribution that occur when muscle or other structures are exerting an influence on the musculoskeletal system.  Another measure to consider is stabilometric variables. Stabilometry is a systematic procedure for detecting changes in trunk and extremity postural sway. In our clinical practice, we often use the Cosmed Kisteler StabilimetersTM which are devices that measure static measures of postural stability, such as sway index, anteroposterior displacement, medial-lateral displacement, and range of motion. Other modalities that may be employed to assess balance include the Romberg test, Star Excursion Balance Test, and force plate assessments. The static footprint and stabilometric procedures have been shown to be valid, reliable, and sensitive measures of treatment effects resulting from either neuromuscular or neurological interventions. I would also suggest having a blinded masked observer assess static postural sway. This is particularly useful if a larger sample size is needed to better assess your treatment effects. Would you like more details on these outcome measure options?

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Pressure muscle index (PMI) as a bedside estimation of inspiratory effort at different expiratory cycling levels during different levels of pressure support ventilation. Measure Description: To verify whether PMI correlates differently with esophageal pressure swing by changing expiratory cycling over different levels of pressure support ventilation. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Correlation between PMI and other measures of inspiratory effort (Pocc) and inspiratory drive (P0.1). Measure Description: To evaluate the correlation between different measures of inspiratory effort and inspiratory drive with PMI obtained at various degrees of expiratory cycling and different levels of pressure support. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.
- Airway resistances during assisted mechanical ventilation. Measure Description: To evaluate if airway resistance, evaluated by esophageal pressure, correlates with the estimation of airway resistance on the pressure-time waveform. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.
- Tidal volume variability. Measure Description: To evaluate tidal variability across different levels of pressure support ventilation and different levels of expiratory cycling and investigate how tidal variability correlates with inspiratory effort using deltaPes, PMI, and Pocc. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.

Measures of health-related quality of life (HRQOL) are becoming increasingly recognized as an important outcome in oncology trials. Health-related quality of life outcomes include assessments addressing functional impairments and health status, but they can differ from clinically meaningful measures of survival or radiographic disease progression. HRQOL assessment is a complex and multidimensional process that is affected by many factors including the site of disease, stage of disease, tumor biology, and the mode and impact of therapy. HRQOL assessment is necessary for clinical trials to characterize the impact of interventions on multiple important facets of a patient's well-being and to assess the overall impact of interventions on a patient's quality of life.

Which countries require approval from an Institutional Review Board (IRB)?
All studies that involve human subjects, regardless of the country in which they are performed, are required to be approved by an IRB.
If your study does not involve the collection of identifiable human data, it may still require ethical approval, but it may not need IRB review depending on the country. For example, studies conducted in Germany can apply for a declaration of exemption from IRB review by the GMO/GCP office of the Ethics Council of the German Primate Center. To determine whether your study requires review by an IRB, contact the national representative for the country in which the research will be conducted.
Which countries require registration?
All clinical trials must be registered in a public registry before being conducted for compliance with many countries' regulatory requirements.
You should contact regulatory affairs at your institution or the relevant professional organizations to determine if your study is considered to be a clinical trial under the laws and regulations of the country in which it is conducted.
Which countries require postmarketing follow-up?
In the United States, many drug and device products require postmarketing follow-up assessments to assess long-term safety and efficacy. Studies are required to monitor side effects on a drug or device, specifically looking for unexpected adverse effects or risks.
You should contact regulatory affairs to determine if the country in which your study is being conducted has similar postmarketing follow-up requirements.
How do I submit a study for regulatory clearance?

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Percentage of patients achieving ICR I: Achieving ICR I is defined as a urine protein-creatinine ratio of less than 1.0 g/gCr. This measure reflects the primary goal of the study.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Percentage of patients who are CR, ICR I, ICR II, NR, or PR: This measure provides a comprehensive evaluation of treatment response in different patient subgroups.
- Duration before achieving CR, ICR I, ICR II, or PR: This measure assesses the time it takes for patients to respond to treatment and achieve different levels of remission or response.
- Changes in urine protein-creatinine ratio: This measure evaluates the impact of rituximab on kidney function and disease progression.
- Differences in eGFR: This measure assesses the effect of rituximab on renal function.
- B-cells (CD19-positive and CD20-positive cells): This measure monitors B-cell counts and helps us understand the mechanism of action of rituximab.
- Expression of HACA: This measure evaluates the safety and immunogenicity of rituximab.
- Serum rituximab (genetical recombination) concentration: This measure helps optimize dosing and ensures adequate drug exposure for efficacy.

To evaluate the hospitalization costs, we can compare the length of hospital stay between patients who received either the Signia Stapler or the Vessel Sealer extend Energy Device. We can monitor and record hospital stay data up to 30 days following surgery to understand the impact of the devices on patient outcomes and hospital costs.

#2 STAGE 2: Feasibility and acceptability of the process
Are the instruments and study materials ready for pilot testing?
Are the timelines for protocol development and data collection feasible and achievable?
Are the study procedures feasible and acceptable to participants?
Are the interim analysis plan acceptable, and are the study procedures sufficient to provide the expected efficiencies?
Note: For some studies, feasibility and acceptability may be the same.
#3 STAGE 3: Quality risk management plan
Are the pilot study results suitable for submission?
Are the quality measures adequate to ensure safety and reliability for the intended population?
Is the study design capable of assuring the quality of the data capture?
Have the training and quality assurance measures been developed and tested?
Identify the timing and procedures for any changes to the quality assurance process and quality control.
Are the staff recruitment and training plans in place to ensure quality data?
Define the process for monitoring for adverse events and quality control of data.
Are there plans for audit and feedback to address quality risks?
#4 STAGE 4: Quality risk management report
Analyze the quality risk management data collected during pilot testing and/or the study.
Finalize the monitoring plan for continued data quality assurance and improvement.
Monitoring during the trial implementation
Document any changes in data capture and analysis, and revise the monitoring plan as necessary.
Quality risk management should be an integral part of the trial from the study design stage through to data analysis and publication of the final study report. Ongoing monitoring for quality risk during implementation ensures the continued adequacy of the quality risk management.

groundtruth: You're absolutely right. Randomization is essential to ensure the validity and reliability of the study results. We can measure the ability to randomize patients by documenting the successful random assignment of patients to either the Signia Stapler group or the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device group. This data should be collected at baseline to establish the comparability of the two groups.

To collect data on the stapler reloads used, we can document the type of stapler reloads used in each surgery. This information can be collected up to 3 weeks post-surgery. Additionally, we can also collect data on the number of stapler reloads used in each procedure. This data will help us evaluate the usage and costs associated with the Signia Stapler.

To collect data on the sealing time, we can measure the duration it takes for the energy device to seal vessels during the surgery. This data can be collected up to 3 weeks post-surgery. Additionally, we can also collect the generator setting of the energy device used in each procedure. This information will provide insights into the performance and efficiency of the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

To measure adverse events and complications, we can record short-term clinical outcomes during patient follow-ups. This includes monitoring any postoperative adverse events and complications up to 3 weeks post-surgery. This data will help us evaluate the safety and efficacy of both the Signia Stapler and the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

To evaluate the intraoperative costs, we can collect and analyze the surgical device costs per surgery in Canadian dollars. This will involve assessing the costs associated with using either the Signia Stapler or the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device. We can collect this data up to 3 weeks following hospital discharge to understand the economic implications of the devices.

To collect and evaluate hospitalization costs, we can record the inpatient hospitalization costs per day following surgery in Canadian dollars. This data should be collected from admission to discharge, up to 14 days. This measure will help us assess the overall economic burden associated with using the Signia Stapler and the Vessel Sealer Extend Energy Device.

The MSRRS is a measure of MS-specific psychological distress. It is designed to measure symptoms such as worry, fear, and distress. The MSRRS assesses the level of risk and resilience to stress-related conditions such as depression, anxiety, and fatigue. Scores range from 10 to 56, with higher scores indicating greater depression, anxiety, and stress. The CI-SE is designed to measure maladaptive and adaptive coping behaviors. It includes five subscales: avoidance, altruism, acceptance, control, and positive reappraisal. Scores range from 0 to 100 for each subscale, with higher scores indicating more maladaptive behaviors and lower scores indicating more adaptive behaviors. The CI-SEL is the long form version of the CI-SE. It includes the additional subscales of escape. Both measures will be used to assess coping behaviors. Well-being will also be assessed using the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) and the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule (PANAS). The SWLS measures the level of satisfaction in one's life. Scores range from 10 to 30, with higher scores indicating greater satisfaction. The PANAS measures positive and negative affect. It includes 20 items assessing the degree of positive affect and 20 items assessing the degree of negative affect. Participants are asked to rate their feelings on 5-point Likert scales, ranging from 1 (not at all) to 5 (extremely). The MS Risk and Resilience Scale, Coping Inventory for Stressful Events - Short Form, Coping Inventory for Stressful Events - Long Form, and Satisfaction with Life Scale were developed by the Sponsor. The Positive and Negative Affect Schedule was adapted from Dr. Friedman.

Of course! The MFIS is a patient-reported outcome measure that assesses the impact of fatigue on individuals with MS. Higher scores reflect greater impact. The PSQI is a self-report measure of sleep quality. Higher scores reflect poorer sleep quality. The PES is a measure of pain self-efficacy. Higher scores reflect greater self-efficacy. The GSES is a measure of self-efficacy more generally. Higher scores reflect greater self-efficacy. The UWSES is a measure of MS-specific self-efficacy. Higher scores reflect greater self-efficacy. The BFIMS is a measure of benefit finding, or the ability to see the good in a situation despite hardships. Higher scores reflect greater benefit finding. The SWLS is a measure of overall quality of life. Higher scores reflect higher quality of life. The RYFFPWB is a measure of subjective well-being. Higher scores reflect greater well-being.
The secondary outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, week 12, and week 24.
groundtruth: Certainly! The secondary outcome measures include the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) - Change in Fatigue, Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) - Change in Sleep, MOS Pain Effects Scale (PES) - Change in Pain, General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) - Change in Self-efficacy, University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale - Change in MS specific self-efficacy, University of Washington Resilience Scale - Change in Resilience, COPE inventory - Change in Coping, Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) - Change in Benefit-finding, Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) - Changes in Quality of Life, Flourishing Scale (FS) - Change in Quality of Life, and Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) - Changes in well-being.

Of course! The Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) measures the level of fatigue in individuals with MS. The Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) assesses the quality of sleep. The MOS Pain Effects Scale (PES) measures the level of pain experienced. The General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) assesses self-efficacy, while the University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale focuses specifically on MS-specific self-efficacy. The University of Washington Resilience Scale measures resilience. The COPE inventory assesses coping strategies. The Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) measures positive coping. The Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS) measures quality of life and satisfaction. The Flourishing Scale (FS) also measures quality of life. Lastly, the Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) assess psychological well-being.

The assessments for the secondary outcome measures will also be conducted at baseline, 12 weeks, and 24 weeks. This allows for an evaluation of changes over time and the effectiveness of the Unified Protocol intervention on various aspects of well-being in individuals with MS.
